items.content_html:
Fixes #13749.

This attempts to clarify the description of event bubbling and capture, especially to make it clearer that capture is the non-default option.
items.title: Rework event bubbling and capture

items.content_html:
Although the current description says;
"You can only change the margins, orphans, widows, and page breaks of the document", but after testing, I found out that only the margin can be changed in the @page at-rule.
Maybe, all the features in the official spec have not been implemented yet? But, this is a small change I think would be useful to all devs that come across this and try it out for the first time.

Summary

It changes the description that says @page can only change the margins, orphans, widows, and page breaks of the document to only the margin can be changed.

Motivation

I came across this at-rule because I was preparing an article for a blog, but after testing I found out that only the margin can be changed. I think other devs that come across this won't waste their time wondering why the other properties were not showing any visible effect

Supporting details

The official documentation says a lot more can be changed, but, those changes also don't have any visible effect after testing. I think implementation for those properties is yet to be done in all UAs.
This is the official doc - https://drafts.csswg.org/css-page/#at-page-rule

Related issues

Not applicable

Metadata

  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: [Correction] Only margin can be changed in @page

items.content_html:
Summary

The "Accessibility concerns" section of the list-style-type page is out of date, and I think the same section in the list-style page could be more clear. Additionally, these pages are inconsistent with each other. This PR addresses these issues.

Motivation

I personally was a bit confused by the accessibility information on these two pages and, after doing some reading and testing on my own, thought I might be able to help clarify and provide some updates.

On the list-style page, I've updated the "Accessibility concerns" section to:

  • Clarify that Safari's behavior is intentional
  • Clarify that adding any pseudo-content before list items will restore list semantics. I was personally uncertain whether only zero-width spaces or images had this effect previously, and thought that other readers might be similarly unsure
  • Make sure that both <ul> and <ol> are mentioned any place where just one was mentioned previously, because Safari's behavior affects both
  • Add more examples
  • Add a link to the relevant WebKit Bugzilla bug
  • Update the link that references WCAG 2.0 to version 2.1

On the list-style-type page, I've updated the "Accessibility concerns" section to defer to the same section of the list-style page. I'm hopeful that this will make it easier to keep these sections in sync with each other, since they address the same issue. I chose to point the content on list-style-type to same on list-style, and not the opposite direction, because one of the provided workarounds involves list-style-image.

Supporting details

The list-style-type page references VoiceOver and list-style-type: none, but it would seem that this article has been updated since the information was added to MDN.

The aforementioned article and MDN's list-style page both reference "Fixing" Lists, which is a helpful source of information on this subject.

I found Bug #170179 | WebKit Bugzilla to be informative here, especially the test case attachment provided by James Craig in Comment 1.

I also manually tested both the original accessibility concern and each workaround given with Safari version 15.6.1 and VoiceOver on desktop to confirm that they behave as stated in this content.

Related issues

I wasn't able to find any related or similar Issues or Pull Requests.

Metadata

This PR...

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Update list-style and list-style-type accessibility concerns

items.content_html:
Summary

The inset CSS property is missing from the list on this page. It's a relatively new shorthand property for top, right, bottom and left.

Motivation

This property isn't all that well-known given that it's fairly new. But it's incredibly useful when styling pseudo-elements, plus it is unique to Positioned layouts.

Supporting details

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/inset

items.content_html:
Summary

Improved code example for fallback on :focus and updated section text to match new code.

Motivation

After replacing the custom button with a native button in the previous change to this example, the styles of the example now affect the native styles of the button. It is better to move the properties that change the appearance of the button itself into its general styles.

In addition, this example has always been difficult to understand for beginners due to different styles for different focus pseudo-classes. Making the example look more realistic and practical will make it more useful for developers.

Supporting details

@simevidas suggested the @supports not selector() method and noticed that setting/resetting background is causing the button to lose the native appearance on click.

And @pepelsbey suggested not styling :focus at all, so older browsers would just have a native focus outline.

This code works well in newer browsers and fallbacks to :focus in older ones as expected. Checked in Safari 14.1:

Kooha-2022-08-24-19-42-56.mp4

Metadata

  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document

items.content_html:
Same as #19185, but for JavaScript pages.

The PR updates tags, headers, and inline badges as per current BCD v5.1.10.
There are only 19 files to update in JavaScript.

Note: We are simply synchronizing it with BCD. If you have objection with any compatibility status then raise an issue or PR in https://github.com/mdn/browser-compat-data repo. After BCD gets updated it'll be updated in JavaScript content automatically.

items.content_html:
On line 191, this updates the second sentence to refer to positive/negative velY values based on the screen coordinate system (with a y-value of 0 being the upper edge of the screen), instead of being based on a Cartesian coordinate system (where the y-value of 0 would be the bottom edge of the screen) as it was before.

Summary

This updates the description of the velY variable, and whether its value is positive or negative, with respect to the vertical axis on the screen where the value 0 is the upper edge of the screen.

Motivation

This change makes the description consistent with the coordinate system used in Canvas elements, where a y-value of 0 represents the upper edge of the screen. The previous wording (for example, the ball traveling upwards when the velY value is positive) represents a Cartesian coordinate instead, and is therefore confusing here.

Supporting details

Related issues

items.title: Interchange 'positive' and 'negative' velY descriptions

Summary

Provides clarification to references that an extension needs to be enabled in private browsing windows for an API or feature to function correctly. This is done by way of a link to the SUMO article describing how users enable an extension to access private browsing windows.

Motivation

To ensure readers understand that extension access to private browsing is under user control.

Related issues

items.content_html:
I think yield await Promise.resolve(1); is misleading, because
Promise.resolve(1); is a promise but
await Promise.resolve(1); is a value 1 (the resolved value of the promise)
yield 1 turns 1 into a promise, but it's a different promise than the Promise.resolve(1)

Summary

Motivation

Supporting details
